q.t: It is vital that modders add configurations to their mods in order to provide users the best experience.
Modding is an art.
Politics should be kept out of mods as it intefers with the user experience.
Modders can use mods as a way of expressing their personal thoughts and feelings.
Configuration comes secondary to providing a developed and functional user experience in a mod.
Modders should show an unbiased front to their community and refrain from making opinionated and political statements.
Making a custom client is fine as long as you don't use it to break server rules.
Modding should only be used to enhance the game experience.
Modding is a valid platform for adding to LGBTQ awareness.
Meme mods don't contribute to the community.
Parody mods support a socially healthy community.
It's a modder's job to prioritise stabilising existing content over adding new content.
Open sourcing is vital for a positive modder-user relationship.
Making your mods open source is an important part of increasing stability and maintainability.
Making parts of your mod data-driven is essential for user customisation and consequently a good user experience.
The developers of the game you are modding have the right to use your code in their product, regardless of your licence, if you accept such terms in the EULA.
Creative commons licences are valid licences for mods.
Mods should ideally be free for everyone.
Modders should be able to make money from downloads on their mods, if they choose.
Supporting multiple languages to make the mod more accessible is equally or almost just as important as developing the mod content.

It's not a modder's requirement to make their mods - they do it in their free time - so if they want to put spending the time and effort to fix difficult bugs behind a paywall it's their right to do so.
The programmer and the designer are more important than the music composer and the artist.
